If a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it came (e.g. if they move over a mountain range or across a river, or if they migrate to a new island so that they cannot easily return), they will often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor, as opposed to what it used to need.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adaptations as before.
As time goes on, the new population begins to adapt to its new environment, and then it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years, two populations look so different that they can no longer be classified as the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the creation of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from the technological push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by a fundamental logic that is linked to scientific laws and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general assumptions. On the one hand, that the development of technology follows a path that is largely beyond the influence of cultural or political factors, and on the other hand, that technology itself has effects on societies that are more inherent than socially determined.
One could argue that the development of roads is inextricably linked to the development of the automobile.
However, a nationwide network of roads for only a small number of cars is not economically viable. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.
The widespread ownership of cars also leads to a higher number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new technologies in the field of healthcare to repair damaged bodies.

Stepping irons are aids for the feet of riders, which hang down on both sides of the saddle.
They give the rider more stability, but there are safety concerns because the rider's feet may get caught in them.
If a rider falls off the horse and gets caught in the stirrup, he can be dragged along if the horse runs. In order to minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First of all, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a relatively narrow, smooth sole.
In addition, some saddles, especially English saddles, have safety buckles that allow a stirrup leather to fall if pulled backwards by a falling rider.
